ï»¿ANNEX 1 Part II Europe 2020 Programmatic Single-Donor Trust Fund Description This Annex shall be applicable to and form an integral part of the Administration Agreement for the Trust Fund between the Bank and the Donor. 1. Objectives The objectives of the Trust Fund are: The European Commission and the Bank share a common objective of building competitive and sustainable economies and reducing poverty and social exclusion - goals of the Europe 2020 Agenda which is built on three pillars of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The European Commission and the Bank concur that direct interaction is beneficial to both institutions and through them to the beneficiary countries. This applies particularly to the provision of analytical, advisory and knowledge services and technical assistance. The European Commission has expressed an interest in ensuring that the Bank continues to provide technical assistance in the framework of the Trust Fund in furtherance of the common objective set forth above. 2. Activities The sub-objectives and description of activities are: 2.1 The European Commission, particularly the Directorate General for Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion, supports the analysis of labour market and social inclusion policies and the development of policy recommendations on the basis of profiles of 'out of work" and 'low work intensity' individuals in its Member States. The activity's overall objective is to inform the EC and EU Member States' labor market activation and social inclusion policies through an improved understanding of the characteristics and labor market barriers of 'out-of work' and 'low-work-intensity' individuals. This includes continued assistance to develop detailed "profiles" or "portraits" of individuals with no or limited labor-market attachment and identify distinct groups of individuals who are the potential clients of income support and employment support policies with the objective of contributing to the decrease of the population that is at risk of poverty or social exclusion by strengthening the empirical basis for analyzing active inclusion. The activities (which may be described as "components" of activities) to be financed by the Trust Fund, in support of the sub-objectives cited in Section 2.1 above, are the following Bank-executed activities, for which the Bank has implementation responsibility: (a) The Bank shall jointly with the OECD prepare a paper describing, applying and illustrating the clustering methodology chosen to derive the salient profiles of 'out-of-work' and 'low-work- intensity' individuals. The description of the joint methodology will be based on EU-SILC data of one or two Member States included in the analysis and will contain a sample Profile Analysis Note (PAN).
ï»¿The paper is intended to provide a guide for interpreting results from the country studies and will include (i) a definition of the target population and a statistical overview of this population in countries included in this Action and in other relevant comparator countries as appropriate; (ii) a detailed presentation of the statistical clustering approach, (iii) a discussion of its rationale, advantages and disadvantages relative to alternative approaches, (iv) a discussion of data issues, measurement choices and limitations; (v) an illustration of the approach using available data for one or two countries. (b) The Bank shall prepare six (6) Country-specific "Profile Analysis Notes" and "Country Policy Papers (CPP)"' of unemployed, inactive and low-work-intensity individuals. The clusters will be derived through the application of a mutually agreed methodology for Latent-Class-Analysis to available EU-SILC data. The Country-specific Cluster Models described in the "Profile Analysis Notes" will be the basis for a more detailed "Country Policy Papers" to be prepared by the Bank describing activation and labor market inclusion barriers for a set of prioritized groups in the respective countries. The prioritized groups will be chosen in dialogue with the country and the EC. The Profile Analysis Notes will contain the following information for each cluster, given the available data quality: - Size. Number of individuals in cluster. - Labor market status. Shares of individuals that are unemployed, long-term unemployed, inactive and in low work intensity. - Labor market barriers. A characterization of the main labor market barriers faced by each cluster. Barriers of incentive, capability and opportunity will be reported and summarized in an intuitive way. - Social inclusion status. Poverty-related indicators (share of individuals in lower income quintiles) will be reported to demonstrate the degree of social inclusion. - Individual life and household situation. Where not already covered by the labor market barriers, characteristics such as age, gender, education, work experience, household composition will be reported. - Patterns of benefit receipt. Shares of individuals receiving specific benefits (unemployment, disability, old-age pension, social assistance, family and child) will be reported in relation to the clusters' labor market status. The resulting groupings will be country specific, driven by the specific demographic, social and economic characteristics of individuals and their household contexts. They are intended to provide a novel and policy-relevant perspective on employment barriers, complementing standard statistical tools and indicators for monitor the situation of people with no or little labour-market attachments (such as common tabulations from labour-force surveys). (c) The Bank shall organize seminars, workshops and participation in joint country missions, audio or video-conferences with EU Member States representatives, European Commission, World Bank, and OECD experts/staff on the Profile Analysis Notes (Country Prioritization Discussion) and on a draft of the Country Policy Papers (Country Dialogue Missions) to present and validate findings, prioritize areas of work within the activity and discuss the application and translation of findings to Member State policies. Unless otherwise agreed with the European Commission the Bank shall carry out this activity in the following EU member States: Bulgaria, Greece, Lithuania, Romania, Croatia, and Poland.
ï»¿(d) The Bank shall jointly with the OECD prepare and present a Final Report collecting, summarizing and synthesizing the findings from the Country Policy Discussion Papers and carry out a project closing seminar with participating Member States representatives, European Commission, World Bank, and OECD experts/staff to discuss the findings gathered in the Final Report Document. (e) The Bank shall jointly with the OECD provide training and capacity building on profiling methodologies and approaches to the participating EU Member States through (i) a brief country data and methodology note, and (ii) a training seminar for application of clustering methodology to available country statistical or administrative data or other activities that deepen the dialogue and policy analysis of the Country Policy Paper. The activities envisioned during such training seminars could include country-to-country virtual peer learning events to facilitate knowledge exchange among focus countries. Background and Rationale for Activity In the European Union, many countries show elevated levels of unemployment, inactivity and long- term unemployment, especially since the onset of the financial and economic crisis in 2008. Prolonged unemployment often goes hand-in-hand with a deteriorating social situation of the households and individuals it affects. In addition to formally declared unemployment, discouraged and demotivated workers together with early retirees and stay-at-home parents, form a group of individuals who are inactive in the labor market. Under the demographic situation in many EU countries -with a shrinking working- age population- inactivity needs to be regarded jointly with unemployment in order to mitigate the effects of aging and rising dependency ratios. ï»¿1. The first, capability, relates to the individual's ability to take on work. For instance, an individual's ability to work could be affected by his or her skills and work experience, as well as by his or her health or disability status. For instance, if there are no sufficient job offers in a particular area, an individual may experience long spells of unemployment or become discouraged from the labor market altogether. Lastly, the third broad category is a lack of incentives. ï»¿2.4 Methodology for Clustering: Latent Class Analysis Descriptive statistics enable the illustration of the heterogeneity of a particular population in a limited number of dimensions. Without other measures, it is challenging to synthetically describe individuals in the population according to their prevailing characteristics. Latent Class Analysis provides a useful tool in this direction. The main purpose of latent class analysis (LCA) is to identify an organizing principle for a complex array of variables. This latent variable model uses "categorical observed variables, representing characteristics, behaviors, symptoms, or the like as the basis for organizing people into two or more meaningful homogeneous subgroups" (Collins and Lanza 2010). Formally, LCA enables a characterization of a categorical latent (unobserved) variable, starting from an analysis of the relationships among several observed variables (named "indicators"), using a maximum likelihood estimation method. The estimation model used in this study also includes covariates, which are "variables that may be used to describe or predict (rather than to define or measure) the latent classes and if active, to reduce classification error" (Vermunt and Magidson, 2005). Through LCA, individuals are scored according to the likelihood of belonging to each of the computed latent classes, and then assigned to the class to which they have the highest posterior probability of belonging (modal assignment) given their observed characteristics. Statistics such as the Bayesian Indicator Criterion (BIC) are used to identify the most appropriate number of classes, that is, the model that has on average the highest likelihood of predicting class membership for all individuals in the given sample. A fundamental assumption underlying LCA is that of local independence, which implies that each of the chosen indicator variables is related to the others uniquely through the latent class membership, and a random error. Advanced computational techniques allow detecting and, in part, controlling for the correlation between the residuals of selected indicators, thus enabling the use of the available information to construct categories. Box 2: Latent class analysis Latent,class analysis (LCA) enables a characterization of categorical latent (unobserved) variables from an analysis of the structure of the relationships among several categorical observed variables, LCA is thus "the classification of similar objects into groups, where the number of groups, as well as their forms is unknown" (Kaufman and RousseeUw, 1990). The method was originally conceived of as an analytic method for survey data. As an exploratory technique, LCA can be used to reduce a set of categorically scored variables into a single latent variable with a set of underlying types or "classes". As a confirmatory method, the latent class model can be used to test hypotheses regarding the researchers' a priori assertions about the structure of the relationship among the observed variables. In this note, LCA was used as an exploratory technique to create the optimal number of groups of out-of-work market individuals with the most similar characteristics. The LCA model can be seen as a probabilistic or model-based variant of traditional non- hierarchical cluster analysis procedures such as the K-means method. Contrary to traditional ad- hoc clustering approaches, the LCA approach to clustering is model-based. Since persons in the same latent class (cluster) cannot be distinguished from each other based on their observed V3, 31-March 2015 17
ï»¿responses, they are similar to each other (homogeneous) with respect to these observed variables. Individuals are hence classified into the class for which they have the highest posterior probability of belonging, given their observed characteristics. LCA is thus most similar to the K-Means approach to cluster analysis in which cases that are "close" to one of K centers are grouped together. In fact LCA can be viewed as a probabilistic variant of K-Means clustering where probabilities are used to define "closeness" to each center. As such, LCA provides a way not only to formalize the K-Means approach in terms of a statistical model, but also to extend the K-Means approach in several directions: flexible distance to the center of the cluster, determination of the optinal number of clusters, inclusion of categorical variables, and inclusion of exogenous variables. First, while K-Means uses an ad-hoc distance measure for classification, the LCA approach allows cases to be classified into clusters using model based posterior membership probabilities estimated by maximum likelihood (ML) methods. Second, LCA provides various diagnostics such as the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) statistic, which helps determine the optimal number of clusters. Third, while K-Means clustering is limited to interval scale quantitative variables for which Euclidean distance measures can be calculated, LCA can be performed on variables of mixed metrics (continuous, categorical (nominal or ordinal), or counts or any combination of these). Fourth, the LCA model can be easily extended to include exogenous variables (covariates). The LCA model with covariates can be written as: f(Y/zj = Z p(x=k1zj)f(yjx=k) Where y, is a vector of dependent (endogenous) indicators for individual i, z is a vector of independent (exogenous) covariate for individual i, x is a nominal latent variable (and k denotes a class, k=1,2,...,K), and f(yfx=k) denotes the joint distribution specified fory, given latent class x=k. For continuous yi, the multivariate normal distribution is used with class-specific means. In addition, the within-class covariance matrices can be assumed to be equal or unequal across classes, and the local independence assumption can be relaxed by applying various structures to the within-class covariance matrices. For variables of other/mixed scale types, local independence among the variables imposes restrictions on second-order as well as to higher-order moments. For the analysis of "Portraits of Labor Market Exclusion" (2013-2014), the out-of-work Individuals constituted the population of interest The population was then restricted to working-age population (individuals aged 16 to 64). As mentioned earlier, age categories, gender, education, economic status, chronic illness and spouse working status represent the observed covariates and were used to predict the inactivity status. In addition to these indicator and active covariates, exogenous variables were included in the model, such as income quintile of household, household composition, urban/rural breakdown, region, economic activity of the spouse, work intensity of households and social protection transfers. For each year, the LCA model wasrun with one to ten classes, leading to ten different estimations. To determine the optimal number of clusters into which the population of interest should be divided, we used two criteria that maximize the cohesion within clusters and the distance between clusters: the Akaike and Bayesian Information Criterion (AIC and BIC).
